Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: VocaliD - Infusing Unique Vocal Identities into Synthesized Speech
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to create custom crafted voices for text-to-speech applications that empower recipients to engage in conversation and be heard in his/her own voice. The company's technology blends a recipient's residual vocal abilities and a matched donor's speech database to craft a personalized voice that combines the recipient's vocal identity with the clarity of the donor's speech. In the United States alone, there are over 2.5 million individuals with speech impairment and 3-5 million individuals with low vision who rely on a limited set of generic, mechanical sounding voices for assisted communication. It is not uncommon for several children in a classroom or adults in a workplace to use the same synthetic voice. Each one of us has a unique voiceprint that conveys our age, gender, race, size, and personality. Until now, this variety and flexibility of voice has not been afforded to users of speech synthesis technology. The company's goal is to give the gift of voice to all those who need and want it to enhance how they learn, work and play.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to engineer personalized synthetic voices that convey the recipient's unique vocal identity. The company's innovation is grounded in the source-filter theory of speech production which divides the speech signal into a source component (the vocal folds) and a filter component (the rest of the vocal tract) that are largely independent. Because source and filter characteristics both contribute to speaker identity, the key challenge is to create an authentic, yet understandable voice by extracting as much identity information from recipient vocalizations as possible and combining it with speech clarity information from the donor. Standard voice conversion methods require large amounts of spoken data from donors and recipients as well as parallel corpora, which are not available for the target applications. This Phase I work will make significant advances toward the design and implementation of a novel automated voice matching and transformation process that leverages a large database of healthy donors' speech to generate personalized synthetic voices from sparse samples of target recipients' vocalizations. Algorithms will be validated using both quantitative and perceptual metrics to assess intelligibility, similarity and naturalness.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Text-to-speech (TTS) technology has been around for decades and though the quality of speech has improved, the voice options remain limited. Mass produced, generic sounding synthetic voices pose a significant barrier for 2.5 Million Americans who must rely on speech generating assistive devices to communicate. Imagine several students with autism or adults with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) all speaking in the same voice. Beyond the social implications, generic TTS voices used in assistive devices impose educational barriers and can hinder personal safety. VocaliD creates the first-ever custom synthetic voices for each child, woman and man who relies on TTS for self-expression. By leveraging our crowdsourced Human Voicebank and proprietary voice matching and blending algorithms; we can create personalized voices at affordable prices -- empowering every customer to express themselves through their own voice.

This SBIR Phase I built upon scientific breakthroughs from the PI’s prior NSF funded research that had resulted in a method for generating customized voices by blending brief samples of a voice recipient’s vocalization with a database of speech from a matched donor. The voice building process, however, was a prohibitively expensive and time-intensive manual process that warranted further research and development. Furthermore, laboratory efforts had operated on donor speech that was chosen on an ad hoc basis based on a small amount of available data. However, with the creation of VocaliD’s Human Voicebank, the speech of several thousand donors was now available, thus necessitating the creation of an automated donor-recipient matching process. 

Intellectual merit: This SBIR Phase I focused on demonstrating feasibility of VocaliD’s custom voice building innovation from both technical and business perspectives. Specifically, we needed to demonstrate that the two components of our voice building process, the voice morphing and the recipient-donor matching, could be converted into streamlined, effective and automated forms. By the completion of Phase I, we achieved both goals and forged ahead to create a full end-to-end voice building process by integrating the matching and morphing processes with a Text-to-Speech engine. We also created a “type-and-talk in your own voice” Android app for demonstration purposes. In addition to our technological advances, we made significant progress on defining and validating the market and developing a business plan through a successful crowdfunding campaign in which we raised $120, 610 (172% of our goal) to secure our first 50 customers via pre-order sales. We also established cooperative agreements with leading assistive communication companies to make our voices compatible with their devices. Having demonstrated the technical and commercial feasibility, VocaliD is uniquely poised to create a paradigm shift from generic to personalized TTS.

Broader Implications: VocaliD's custom voices empower those users of TTS to be heard as themselves. Not only do our customers benefit, but family members can connect with their loved ones at an entirely new level; teachers can differentiate among their students who rely of talking devices to communicate; and strangers can hear a glimmer of personality hidden behind the talking device. These opportunities for social connection increase independence and access to educational and vocational resources that can narrow the gap between those with and without disability. VocaliD's Human Voicebank and voice matching and blending technology infrastructure also open up new TTS markets. With increasing reliance on speech interfaces for automated assistants, social robots, and the 'internet of things', there will be increased demand for personalized TTS.
